Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project spans the petrochemical, medical, and energy industries. The protective coatings developed in this project will allow for safer storage, transportation, and use of corrosive chemicals, as well as the containment and treatment of hazardous wastes. These coatings may also find application to medical instruments and devices, allowing longer lifetimes and lower risks of contamination. The same coatings will also be useful in improved electrochemical systems such as fuel cells and electrolyzers, which will allow for effective use of renewable energy. Because this technology allows the deposition of iridium oxide coatings that are only a few atoms thick, the virtues of iridium oxides can be imbued to surfaces using fractions of a percent of the iridium required by currently employed methods. This will improve the applicability of this rare, and otherwise cost-prohibitive element.

This I-Corps project starts with a technology that allows the room-temperature deposition of iridium oxide coatings from a molecular organometallic precursor dissolved in water. The coatings are only a few atoms thick, but have been shown to be as impervious as iridium oxide coatings 500 times thicker, and more active than the thicker coatings as electrocatalysts for the oxidation of water and small organic molecules. Additionally, the coatings are electrically conductive. During this I-corps project, the team will gather information from potential customers to develop products that will best take advantage of this ultra-thin, protective and catalytically active coating. It is envisioned that this will be a transformative technology in some sectors, allowing devices and systems with unprecedented functionality and durability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was quite successful. We began the NSF I-CORPS program with some very exciting technologies from the laboratory, and a general sense that they would be useful for many electrochemiscal applications. By the end of the program, we had interviewed over 100 potential customers, partners and competitors, and used the results of our interviews to guide our understanding of the market forces and players, which we then applied to the development and redevelopment of our business plan. In our final presentation in the I-CORPS , we announced that we "are a go," indicating that we had determined we had a viable and scalable business model. Since completing the program, we have incorporated as a Delaware C-Corp, formed a partnership with the company our business mentor is in as well as a few partnerships formed with companies that some of our interviewees were affiliated with, and have hired two full-time non-founder employees.

Our first ideas of target customers included industrial applications such as zinc smelting, commercial electroplating, electrochemical treatment of wastewater, and energy storage devices like batteries or fuel cells. We eliminated smelting and electroplating within the first week of interviews, and shifted focus to energy storage and wastewater treatment.

We found that both of these markets are highly sensitive to their regulatory environment. Wastewater treatment in particular, is built around regulatory standards and limits (and enformecement). It is rare that companies volunteer to invest in a more rigorous treatment than is required, and new technologies are viewed very skeptically until they have been shown to be in compliance with regulations. Similarly, for energy storage, especially renewable energy storage, efficiency standards and price of energy are a very important aspects for the market.

For these reasons, we were attracted to markets in the EU, where environmental regulations and efficiency standards are tighter, and companies are more interested in gaining a technological edge for acheiving these more stringent standards economcially. With the blessings of the program director, our entreprenurial lead travelled to Europe to meet with people developping hydrogen cars and fueling stations, fuel cell manufacturers, and companies working on power-to-gas energy storage for the emerging European wind and solar markets.

Based on the positive feedback in Europe and budding potential for domestic partnerships, we used the final moments of the program as a springboard to launch our company, Catalytic Innovations Inc.

Ultimately, in addition to starting this company, which is doing well so far, we all learned a lot about the process of tehcnology commercialization. I can bring this knowledge back to my University and use what I know to direct my research more productively, and train my students to have a more "real-world" eye for what is important in their science.  And if that isn't a successful outcome of the I-CORPS program, I don't know what is.

Thank you.


Last Modified: 05/22/2017
Modified by: Aaron Bloomfield
